description: Borrowed from Late Latin populatio (“a people, multitude”), as if a noun of action from Classical Latin populus. Doublet of poblacion.

entries.meaning: The people living within a political or geographical boundary.
examples: The population of New Jersey will not stand for this!

entries.meaning: (by extension) The people with a given characteristic.
examples: India has the third-largest population of English-speakers in the world.

entries.meaning: A count of the number of residents within a political or geographical boundary such as a town, a nation or the world.
(biology) A collection of organisms of a particular species, sharing a particular characteristic of interest, most often that of living in a given area.
examples: A seasonal migration annually changes the populations in two or more biotopes drastically, many twice in opposite senses.

entries.meaning: (statistics) A group of units (persons, objects, or other items) enumerated in a census or from which a sample is drawn.
examples: […] it is possible it [the Anglo-Saxon race] might stand second to the Scandinavian countries [in average height] if a fair sample of their population were obtained.

entries.meaning: (computing) The act of filling initially empty items in a collection.
examples: John clicked the Search button and waited for the population of the list to complete.
